TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit JumpTask extends System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem

Docs.summary: Represents a shortcut to an application in the Windows 7 taskbar Jump List.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> can be thought of as a shortcut to an application. You specify the path to the executable file by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.ApplicationPath%2A> property. If the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.ApplicationPath%2A> is not set, the path of the current running process is implied. You can optionally specify <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.Arguments%2A> to pass to the application at startup.
You can set basic display properties, such as <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.Title%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.Description%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.IconResourcePath%2A> to specify the appearance of the task in the Jump List. An icon used with a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> must be available as a native resource. If multiple icon resources are available in a DLL or executable file, you specify the one to use by indicating an offset in the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.IconResourceIndex%2A> property.
By default, a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> will be placed in the **Tasks** category of the Jump List. You can specify custom grouping of tasks by setting the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem.CustomCategory%2A> property.
You can visually separate items in a Jump List by creating a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> that does not have a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.Title%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem.CustomCategory%2A> specified. This empty <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> will be displayed as a horizontal line in the Jump List. In this case, other properties can be set, but they will not have any effect.
## Examples The following example shows how to declare a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> in markup. The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> opens a text file named `readme.txt` in the Notepad application.
[!code-xaml[Shell_JumpListSample#002](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/shell_jumplistsample/cs/app.xaml#002)]
The following example shows how to configure a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> in code. The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> opens the Calculator application.
[!code-csharp[Shell_JumpListSample#241](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/shell_jumplistsample/cs/mainwindow.xaml.cs#241)]

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
Gets or sets the path to the application.
Docs.value: The path to the application. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.ApplicationPath%2A> property is not specified, then the path of the current running process is implied. An application can contain tasks for executables other than itself.
## Examples The following example shows how to declare a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> in markup. The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> opens a text file named `readme.txt` in the Notepad application.
[!code-xaml[Shell_JumpListSample#002](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/shell_jumplistsample/cs/app.xaml#002)]
The following example shows how to configure a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> in code. The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> opens the Calculator application.
[!code-csharp[Shell_JumpListSample#241](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/shell_jumplistsample/cs/mainwindow.xaml.cs#241)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the zero-based index of an icon embedded in a resource.
Docs.value: The zero-based index of the icon, or -1 if no icon is used. The default is 0.

remarks.format:
## Remarks An icon used with a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> must be available as a native resource. If multiple icons are available in a DLL or executable file, you specify the one to use by indicating an offset in the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.IconResourceIndex%2A> property.
If no icon resource is specified, or if the specified icon is not found, the standard system icon is displayed. To specify that no icon is displayed, set the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.IconResourceIndex%2A> property to -1.
## Examples The following example shows how to declare a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> in markup. The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> opens a text file named `readme.txt` in the Notepad application.
[!code-xaml[Shell_JumpListSample#002](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/shell_jumplistsample/cs/app.xaml#002)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the path to a resource that contains the icon to display in the Jump List.
Docs.value: The path to a resource that contains the icon. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks An icon used with a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> must be available as a native resource. If multiple icons are available in a DLL or executable file, you specify the one to use by indicating an offset in the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.IconResourceIndex%2A> property.
If no icon resource is specified, or if the specified icon is not found, the standard system icon is displayed. To specify that no icon is displayed, set the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.IconResourceIndex%2A> property to -1.
## Examples The following example shows how to declare a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> in markup. The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> opens a text file named `readme.txt` in the Notepad application.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the text displayed for the task in the Jump List.
Docs.value: The text displayed for the task in the Jump List. The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Typically, the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.Title%2A> property must be set for the <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> to appear in the Jump List as a clickable task.
Alternatively, you can visually separate items in a Jump List by creating a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> that does not have a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask.Title%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpItem.CustomCategory%2A> specified. This empty <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> will be displayed as a horizontal line in the Jump List. In this case, other properties can be set, but they will not have any effect.
## Examples The following example shows how to declare a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> in markup. The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> opens a text file name `readme.txt` in the Notepad application.
[!code-xaml[Shell_JumpListSample#002](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/shell_jumplistsample/cs/app.xaml#002)]
The following example shows how to configure a <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> in code. The <xref:System.Windows.Shell.JumpTask> opens the Calculator application.
[!code-csharp[Shell_JumpListSample#241](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Wpf/shell_jumplistsample/cs/mainwindow.xaml.cs#241)]
